articles.headline: Ozy Media’s Founder, Carlos Watson, Arrested on Fraud Charges
articles.snippet: Mr. Watson had founded the troubled digital-media start-up Ozy, which unraveled after The New York Times examined its business practices.
articles.abstract: Mr. Watson had founded the troubled digital-media start-up Ozy, which unraveled after The New York Times examined its business practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Carlos Watson, the founder of the troubled digital start-up Ozy Media, was arrested on Thursday and charged with multiple counts of fraud, punctuating one of the more precipitous falls in the annals of online journalism.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mullin, Katie Robertson and Ben Protess

articles.headline: ‘Woodstock’ for Christians: Revival Draws Thousands to Kentucky Town
articles.snippet: Over two weeks, more than 50,000 people descended on a small campus chapel to experience the nation’s first major spiritual revival in decades — one driven by Gen Z.
articles.abstract: Over two weeks, more than 50,000 people descended on a small campus chapel to experience the nation’s first major spiritual revival in decades — one driven by Gen Z.
articles.lead_paragraph: WILMORE, Ky. — Jennifer Palmer told her boss on Thursday morning that she had to leave work, and drove 11 hours straight from Jacksonville, Fla., to get here.
articles.byline: By Ruth Graham and Jesse Barber

articles.headline: In Fog of East Palestine’s Crisis, Politicians Write Their Own Stories
articles.snippet: The train derailment in Eastern Ohio has spawned conspiracy theories and contradictory narratives, with politicians from both parties parading through town to further their agendas.
articles.abstract: The train derailment in Eastern Ohio has spawned conspiracy theories and contradictory narratives, with politicians from both parties parading through town to further their agendas.
articles.lead_paragraph: To Democrats, the train derailment and chemical leak in the hamlet of East Palestine, Ohio, is a story of logic, action and consequences: Rail safety regulations put in place by the Obama administration were intended to prevent just such accidents. The Trump administration gutted them.

articles.headline: Shattered Homes and Lurking Disease: Quake Hardships Pile Up
articles.snippet: Hundreds of thousands are sheltering in tents, breathing air thick with pollutants unleashed from tombs of rubble, fearful that a new disaster could strike at any moment.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of thousands are sheltering in tents, breathing air thick with pollutants unleashed from tombs of rubble, fearful that a new disaster could strike at any moment.
articles.lead_paragraph: After powerful earthquakes struck southern Turkey, Eylem Sahutoglu and her family endured two weeks of freezing nights under a blue tarpaulin. Then word came from government engineers who had inspected their building: They could return home.
articles.byline: By Cora Engelbrecht and Nimet Kirac

articles.headline: ‘It’s Complicated’: How Biden and Zelensky Forged a Wartime Partnership
articles.snippet: The relationship between the two leaders has become critical to the future of the international order.
articles.abstract: The relationship between the two leaders has become critical to the future of the international order.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After Russia invaded Ukraine last year, President Biden reflected privately on his long-distance conversations with President Volodymyr Zelensky. He did not know the man well — and might never get to. It was chilling, several people remember him observing grimly, to think that he might be talking with a dead man.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: The E.S.G. Fight Has Come to This: Bankers Suing Lawyers
articles.snippet: Kentucky passed a law targeting banks and their climate policies. Bankers sued the attorney general. Whose definition of investment risk should prevail?
articles.abstract: Kentucky passed a law targeting banks and their climate policies. Bankers sued the attorney general. Whose definition of investment risk should prevail?
articles.lead_paragraph: Bow-tied bankers do not often sue a state’s lawyer in chief. So when it does happen, it’s time to pop the popcorn and gather around to watch.

articles.headline: The Fed’s Preferred Inflation Gauge Sped Back Up
articles.snippet: Inflation is down from its peak last summer, but recent readings have shown substantial and surprising staying power.
articles.abstract: Inflation is down from its peak last summer, but recent readings have shown substantial and surprising staying power.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was a moment, late last year, when everything seemed to be going according to the Federal Reserve’s plan: Inflation was slowing, consumers were pulling back and the overheated economy was gently cooling down.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman
